review.title: A Uniqueness Theorem for Clustering
review.abstract: Despite the widespread use of Clustering, there is distressingly little general theory of clustering available. Questions like "What distinguishes a clustering of data from other data partitioning?", "Are there any principles governing all clustering paradigms?", "How should a user choose an appropriate clustering algorithm for a particular task?", etc. are almost completely unanswered by the existing body of clustering literature. We consider an axiomatic approach to the theory of Clustering. We adopt the framework of Kleinberg, [Kle03]. By relaxing one of Kleinberg's clustering axioms, we sidestep his impossibility result and arrive at a consistent set of axioms. We suggest to extend these axioms, aiming to provide an axiomatic taxonomy of clustering paradigms. Such a taxonomy should provide users some guidance concerning the choice of the appropriate clustering paradigm for a given task. The main result of this paper is a set of abstract properties that characterize the Single-Linkage clustering function. This characterization result provides new insight into the properties of desired data groupings that make Single-Linkage the appropriate choice. We conclude by considering a taxonomy of clustering functions based on abstract properties that each satisfies.

sections.heading: More related work
sections.text: As mentioned above, our formal framework is based on Kleinberg's [Kle03]. We also adopt two of the three axioms, consistency and scale invariance proposed in this paper. We replace the Richness paper of [Kle03] with its version for the case of the fixed number of clusters, k-Richness. Another axiomatic approach is the work of Jardine and Sibson [JS75]. They restrict their view of cluster functions and consider only hierarchical functions. They show that single linkage is the only function that satisfies a number of properties; however, this is primarily a consequence of the fact that one of their properties is an implicit optimization criterion that is optimized solely by single linkage. Our collection of properties differs drastically from [JS75] and does not restrict formalism to taking only hierarchical functions into account. Moreover, none of our properties implicitly reduces the single linkage criterion optimizing, and we do not show all of our characteristics to uniformity.

sections.heading: Formal Preliminaries
sections.text: A partitioning function acts on a set of S of n ≥ 2 points together with an integer k > 0, and pairs of distances between the points in S. The points in S are not assumed to belong to a particular group; the pairs of distances are the only data that the partitioning function has about them. Since we want to deal with dot sets that do not necessarily belong to a particular group, we identify the points with the set S = {1, 2,..., n}. We can then define a distance function that each function d: S × S → R has in such a way that for different i, j в S, d (i, j) ≥ 0, d (i, j) = 0 if and only if i = j, and d (i, j) = d (j).In other words, d must be symmetrical and two points have distance zero if they are just the same dot. Sometimes we write d = < e1, e2, e2) > to mean the set of edges.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusions & future directions
sections.text: In this paper, we take a step towards the important and ambitious goal of developing a general theory of clustering. Specifically, we aim to develop a set of abstract properties of clustering that will bring about a taxonomy of clustering. Such a taxonomy should serve to use previous domain knowledge to enable an educated selection of a cluster method that is suitable for a given clustering task. At this point, we present a unified axiomatic basis for clustering, and in this context, we offer a set of concrete properties that characterize the single linkage cluster algorithm. Our contribution provides new insights into the connection between minimum spanning trees and the single linkage cluster functions. This uniqueness result is set within a framework that resembles the purpose of demonstrating impossibility, and shows that there is no inherent impossibility in the formalization of clustering.
